While the Resolutions of Tynwald (the local Parliament) require confirmation by the Imperial Parliament, it wotild be unprecedent-dented for us to alter them.Resolutions in the Court of Tynwald have effect for six months from the date of the Resolutions, and if Parliament is then in session until the end of the then current session, but unless the Resolutions are confirmed by an Act, they cease to have statutory force at the end of that time. The Resolutions confirmed by this Bill were passed on the 9th June and 7th July.The effect of the Resolutions confirmed by this Bill is as follows:-Tobacco. Note on the "Common Purse" Arrangement,, In cases whore the Isle of Han Customs duties differ from those in force in the United Kingdom, the proceeds are paid direct to the Insular Exchequer. V/here the duties are the same, the "Common irrangomont is in operation; the whole duty is paid into the Imperial Exchequer, and the Island is subsequently credited with the amount of duty payable on its estimated consumption of such articles, calculated by multiplying tho resident population plus an artificial "fiscal equivalent" for visitors by the average consumption per head in the United Kingdom. The true "fiscal population" is ascertained at intervals of 10 years by obtaining returns of the actual imports to the Island of the articles in question, and dividing the total duty value ox such imports by the total duty value of tho consumption per head of similar articles in tho United Kingdom for the same year. The "fiscal equivalent" for visitors in that year is then obtained by deducting the resident population from the ascertained "fiscal population" and is varied in subsequent years in proportion to the annual increase or decrease in the number of visitors.Treasury Chambers, 11th July, 1925.
